occurrences.line_text: Nor happie howre, beheld with gazefull eye,
But Terpine borne to'a more vnhappy howre,
Went on his way, ne euer howre did cease,
Which hauing got, he gan forth from that howre
Weening her lifes last howre then neare to bee,
And on the top a Diall told the timely howres.
Consumed had their goods, and thriftlesse howres,
Was wont his howres and holy things to bed;
Yet howsoeuer base and meane it were,
For howsoeuer it may grow mis-shapt,
From whence eftsoones arriued here three hoyes
And shrieking Hububs them approching nere,
Was hight Sir Huddibras, an hardy man;
But Huddibras, more like a Malecontent,
Next Huddibras his realme did not encrease,
The hue and cry was raysed all about;
Her huge long taile her den all ouerspred,
Lept fierce vpon his shield, and her huge traine
Huge heapes of mudd he leaues, wherein there breed
Huge routs of people did about them band,
And Sisyphus an huge round stone did reele
Where in a dongeon deepe huge numbers lay
Whiles Vna with huge heauinesse opprest,
With huge force and insupportable mayne,
But when as monsters huge he would dismay,
And heaped with so huge misfortunes, reach?
An huge great Dragon horrible in sight,
Vnto his foe, a Gyant huge and tall,
His weapon huge, that heaued was on hye
That huge great body, which the Gyaunt bore,
Which troubled once, into huge flames will grow,
High heaped vp with huge iniquitie,
And eke huge mountaines from their natiue seat
For dread of that huge feend emprisond be
And made wide shadow vnder his huge wast;
His huge long tayle wound vp in hundred foldes,
And hath for twelue huge labours high extold,
Of his huge taile he quite a sunder cleft,
Huge flames, that dimmed all the heauens light,
So downe he fell, as an huge rockie clift,
So huge and horrible a masse it seem'd;
The Amazon huge riuer now found trew?
Hath with so huge misfortune you opprest?
More huge in strength, then wise in workes he was,
They heapt huge strokes, the scorned life to quell,
And both attonce their huge blowes downe did sway;
A couetous desire with his huge threasury.
Of which the matter of his huge desire
So huge a masse, and hide from heauens eye?
Like an huge caue, hewne out of rocky clift,
But huge great yron chests and coffers strong,
Like an huge Gyant of the Titans race,
The massy roofe, and riches huge sustayne,
On th'other side, in huge perplexity,
An huge great paire of bellowes, which did styre
A labour huge, exceeding farre my might:
Of stature huge, and eke of courage bold,
Which that huge sonne of hideous Albion,
So huge and infinite their numbers were,
And planted there their huge artillery,
But two then all more huge and violent,
An huge great stone, which stood vpon one end,
Gan heap huge strokes on him, as ere he downe was cast.
In th'huge abysse of his engulfing graue,
Of huge Sea monsters, such as liuing sence dismayd.
Huge Ziffius, whom Mariners eschew
And the moist daughters of huge Atlas stroue
Like an huge Aetn' of deepe engulfed griefe,
When too huge toile and labour them constraines:
Huge hostes of men he could alone dismay,
Great Gormond, hauing with huge mightinesse
And an huge hoste into Northumber lead,
Yet after all these sorrowes, and huge hills
Nor vengeaunce huge relent it selfe at last?
The huge Orsilochus, I swell with great disdaine.
Huge sea of sorrow, and tempestuous griefe,
All the huge threasure, which the sea below
To sorrow huge she turnd her former play,
An huge eternall Chaos, which supplyes
And with huge strokes, and cruell battery
She caught in hand an huge great yron mace,
Makes the huge element against her kind
So huge a scope at first him seemed best,
So huge a mind could not in lesser rest,
Saue an huge nation of the Geaunts broode,
Into huge waues of griefe and gealosye
Huge monsters haunt, and many dangers dwell;
Threates with huge ruine him to fall vpon,
From an huge Geaunt, that with hideous
There an huge heape of singulfes did oppresse
What huge heroicke magnanimity
With huge impatience he inly swelt,
Besides the huge massacres, which he wrought
The huge seas vnder her t'obay her seruaunts law.
For so huge mischiefe, and vile villany
Of huge affection, did in pleasure melt,
Nations captiued, and huge armies slaine:
An huge great speare, such as he wont to wield,
All which at once huge strokes on him did pound,
With huge great hammers, that did neuer rest
So huge his hammer and so fierce his heat,
Heaping huge strokes, as thicke as showre of hayle,
With huge great teeth, like to a tusked Bore:
And ouer it his huge great nose did grow,
The hideous noise of their huge strokes did heare,
Of stature huge, and horrible of hew,
Of an huge Geauntesse whylome was bred;
Deepe in the bottome of an huge great rocke
And huge Orion, that doth tempests still portend.
And that huge Riuer, which doth beare his name
So huge their numbers, and so numberlesse their nation.
And layd on load with his huge yron flaile,
An huge great paire of ballance in his hand,
So was the high aspyring with huge ruine humbled.
Such an huge stroke, that it of sence distraught her:
With huge redoubled strokes she on him layd;
For his huge club, which had subdew'd of old
And in his hand an huge long staffe he held,
Gan driue at him, with so huge might and maine,
An huge great Lyon lay, that mote appall
For his huge powre and great oppression,
And in her necke a Castle huge had made,
Amid their shields, with so huge might and maine,
With so huge rigour, that his mortall speare
There with huge terrour, to be more ydrad,
And with his huge great yron axe gan hew
Ere that huge stroke arriued on him neare,
An huge great Beast it was, when it in length
Tho with her huge long taile she at him strooke,
So was he stound with stroke of her huge taile.
With his huge flaile began to lay about;
And in his hand an huge Polaxe did beare,
Of stature huge and hideous he was,
And their huge strokes full daungerously bestow,
Yet the huge stroke, which he before intended,
With so huge force, that seemed nothing might
So hideous is her shape, so huge her hed,
And on them layd so huge and horribly,
But ioyning close, huge lode at him did lay:
And eeke of person huge and hideous,
With such huge strokes, approued oft in fight,
So huge a burden on such broken geare,
That huge great foole oppressing th'other Knight,
And makes huge hauocke, whiles the candlelight
But Calidore with huge resistlesse might,
So hugely stroke, that it the steele did riue,
With heaped strokes more hugely, then before,
Strooke him so hugely, that through great constraint
Smote him so hugely on his haughtie crest,
He stroke so hugely with his borrowd blade,
Strooke him so hugely, that in swowne he lay,
As when the Mast of some well timbred hulke
The worke of heauens will surpasseth humaine thought.
Such chaunces oft exceed all humaine thought:
And cride to heauen, from humane helpe exild.
As of humane, that they may altred bee,
So milde humanity, and perfect gentle mynd.
(Their Chieftaine Humber named was aright)
Ne storming Humber, though he looked stout;
All whom a Scythian king, that Humber hight,
Which the proud Humber vnto them had donne,
And raise my thoughts too humble and too vile,
And mightie proud to humble weake does yield,
With humble seruice to her will prepard:
Of her high throne, where they on humble knee
And running Heralds humble homage made,
Their harts she ghesseth by their humble guise,
She to her Sire made humble reuerence,
Vouchsafe to stay your steed for humble misers sake.
He stayd his steed for humble misers sake,
Then loud he cryde, I am your humble thrall.
The Porter eke to her did lout with humble gestes.
And to her homage made, with humble grace:
Presume so high to stretch mine humble quill?
And thought her to adore with humble spright;
At hand with humble pride, and pleasing guile,
In lofty lookes to hide an humble mind,
Did to that image bow their humble knee,
And humble homage did vnto him make,
Some while he thought, by faire and humble wise
Made humble suit vnto his Maiestie,
She did prostrate, and with right humble hart,
With humble prayers and intreatfull teares;
Then taking humble leaue of that great Queene,
Who with right humble thankes him goodly greeting,
Gan stoupe, and falling downe with humble awe,
With humble seruice, and with daily sute,
So was the high aspyring with huge ruine humbled.
But as he lay vpon the humbled gras,
And her adored with due humblenesse,
And to your mighty will. Her humblesse low
And with faire fearefull humblesse towards him shee came.
Themselues to ground with gratious humblesse bent,
Where falling flat, great humblesse he did make,
Tho turning all his pride to humblesse meeke,
With humblest suit that he imagine mot,
Their backward bent knees teach her humbly to obay.
He humbly louted in meeke lowlinesse,
Who well them greeting, humbly did requight,
And at their feet her selfe most humbly feld,
Do one, or other good, I you most humbly pray.
Besought them humbly, him to beare withal,
And humbly thanked him a thousand sith,
And then those Knights he humbly did beseech,
She then began them humbly to intreate,
At last fell humbly downe vpon his knee,
Therefore I humbly craue your Maiestie,
To whom their sute they humbly did present,
And humbly gan that mightie Queene entreat,
She humbly thankt him for that wondrous grace,
And humbly praid to let them in that night:
So humbly taking leaue, she turnd aside,
And through his humid eyes did sucke his spright,
And humid euening ill for sicke folkes cace:
That now the humid night was farforth spent,
Now gan the humid vapour shed the ground
Nights humid curtaine from the heauens withdrew,
Streight at his foot in base humilitee,
That they were borne to base humilitie,
That made him stoupe to ground with meeke humilitie.
Arriued, shee with great humility
Hight Humiltï¿½. They passe in stouping low;
But Trompart, that his maisters humor knew,
His daintie corse, proud humors to abate,
Were deckt with smyles, that all sad humors chaced,
And the sad humour loading their eye liddes,
And for her humour fitting purpose faine,
Whiles euery sence the humour sweet embayd,
His idle humour with fine flattery,
To feede her foolish humour, and vaine iolliment.
Christalline humour dropped downe apace.
To feed her humour with his pleasing stile,
The Christall humour stood congealed rownd;
With heate and humour, breedes the liuing wight.
A filthy bloud, or humour rancorous,
The drowzie humour of the dampish night,
From vnder which the deawy humour shed,
To feede the humour of her maladie;
Of dreaded daunger might his doubtfull humour feed.
The poysnous humour, which did most infest
Her deawy humour gan on th'earth to shed,
Nine hundred Pater nosters euery day,
And thrise nine hundred Aues she was wont to say.
His huge long tayle wound vp in hundred foldes,
As hundred ramping Lyons seem'd to rore,
With hundred yron chaines he did him bind,
And hundred knots that did him sore constraine:
Therein an hundred raunges weren pight,
And hundred fornaces all burning bright;
Which had seuen hundred yeares this scepter borne,
Her Host two hundred thousand numbred is;
Whom Romane warres, which now foure hundred yeares,
Soone after which, three hundred Lordes he slew
Euen seuen hundred Princes, which maintaynd
For ere two hundred yeares be full outronne,
An hundred knights of honorable name
Three hundred pledges for my good desartes,
And thrise three hundred thanks for my good partes
It is not yron bandes, nor hundred eyes,
An hundred knights had him enclosed round,
And after these an hundred Ladies moe
Vpon an hundred marble pillors round
An hundred Altars round about were set,
And eke an hundred brasen caudrons bright,
All which not if an hundred tongues to tell,
And hundred mouthes, and voice of brasse I had,
With hundred turrets, like a Turribant.
An hundred times about the pit side fares,
For since the terme of fourteene hundred fyeres,
They were an hundred knights of that array;
All were they nigh an hundred knights of name:
So dreadfully his hundred tongues did bray,
An hundred naked maidens lilly white,
And feed an hundred flocks, there now not one he found.
By force, he gan his hundred tongues apply,
For twise foure hundreth yeares shalbe supplide,
And with it hung himselfe, vnbid vnblest.
And all within the riuen walls were hung
And feeble hope hung all this while suspence,
And on her shoulder hung her shield, bedeckt
He caused them be hung in all mens sight,
And hung the head, soone as few drops of raine
Hung loose and loathsomely: Thereto her hew
He by the heeles him hung vpon a tree,
As when a greedie Wolfe through hunger fell
Paine, hunger, cold, that makes the hart to quake;
Whom rauenous hunger did thereto constraine:
The whiles he steru'd with hunger and with drouth
The greedy hunger of reuenging ire,
(O hideous hunger of dominion) hither came.
Through hunger long, that hart to him doth lend,
And chearelesse hunger, they together spent;
O Sacred hunger of ambitious mindes,
Tho when they had their hunger slaked well,
As if that hungers point, or Venus sting
As when two Tygers prickt with hungers rage,
Both hungred after death: both chose to win, or die.
On which she fed, and gnawed hungrily,
The cursed Serpent, though she hungrily
Forgetfull of the hungry rage, which late
And who with gracious bread the hungry feeds,
And hungry Wolues continually did howle,
His office was, the hungry for to feed,
Of hungry eies, which n'ote therewith be fild,
Of hungry whelpes, his battailous bold brood,
Whereas the hungry Spaniels she does spy,
With wonder of her beauty fed their hungry vew.
Yet note their hungry vew be satisfide,
More hard for hungry steed t'abstaine from pleasant lare.
And bid him eate, henceforth he oft shall hungry sit.
Are met at spoyling of some hungry pray,
And eke his steedes like to an hungry hound,
And if he hungry were, him offred eke to eat.
On which his hungry eye was alwayes bent;
Like as a sort of hungry dogs ymet
Then gan the Hunnes and Picts inuade this land,
Then hunt the steps of pure vnspotted Maid:
To hunt for glorie and renowmed praise;
To hunt the saluage beast in forrest wyde,
To hunt out perils and aduentures hard,
Which hunt for honor, raised from below,
Doe hunt for shade, where shrowded they may lie,
And after fame and honour for to hunt,
And then againe resolu'd to hunt him out
That she to hunt the beast first tooke in hond;
And all about the fields like Squirrels hunt;
To hunt the saluage chace amongst my peres,
Sometimes I hunt the Fox, the vowed foe
Rather then hunt still after shadowes vaine
And by such trafficke after gaines to hunt,
Which when by tract they hunted had throughout,
But he him hunted like a Foxe full fast:
Of hunter swift, and sent of houndes trew.
How that a noble hunteresse did wonne,
A goodly Ladie clad in hunters weed,
Into the hunters toile, doth rage and rore,
And by his side his hunters horne he hanging had.
And through long labours huntest after fame,
Hunting full greedie after saluage blood;
By hunting and by spoiling liued then;
Now like a Lyon, hunting after spoile,
Was hunting then the Libbards and the Beares,
That hunting after game hath carrion found,
Was hunting in the woods (as was his trade)
Thence doth by Huntingdon and Cambridge flit;
Hippolytus a iolly huntsman was,
Both charet swift and huntsman ouercast.
Which being wounded of the huntsmans hand
And knighthood tooke of good Sir Huons hand,
And hurld his glistring beames through gloomy aire.
His eyes did hurle forth sparkles fiery red,
And hurle not flashing flames vpon that Paynim bold?
Or strike, or hurle, round in warelike gyre,
Hurled his beame so scorching cruell hot,
His hideous tayle then hurled he about,
He hurles out vowes, and Neptune oft doth blesse:
Hurles forth his thundring dart with deadly food,
And rushed forth, hurling her hideous taile
Tho hurling high his yron braced arme,
Then hurling vp his harmefull blade on hye,
Hurling his sword away, he lightly lept
Thereof great hurly burly moued was
And him encombred sore, but could not hurt at all.
Making her death their life, and eke her hurt their good.
And oft for dread of hurt would him aduise,
He hath no powre to hurt, nor to defend;
For hardly could be hurt, who was already stong.
And oft himselfe he chaunst to hurt vnwares,
Of whom sore hurt, for his reuenge
That he his foe has hurt, and wounded sore,
Nought could he hurt, but still at ward did ly:
As hurt he had not bene. Thereby there lay
Wounds without hurt, a bodie without might,
Hart that is inly hurt, is greatly eased
Of hurt vnwist most daunger doth redound:
His grieuous hurt to garish, that she might,
She his hurt thigh to him recur'd againe,
But hurt his hart, the which before was sound,
And hurt far off vnknowne, whom euer she enuide.
That he thereby receiu'd no hurt at all,
As she were neuer hurt, was soone restor'd:
To hurt good knights, was as it were her baude,
But that he her must hurt, or hazard neare:
Betwixt him and his hurt bene happily,
Of his old hurt, which was not throughly cured.
Yet nought they could him hurt, ne ought dismay.
Yet would he not him hurt, although he might:
Fayles of her souse, and passing by doth hurt no more.
Whence he assayd to rise, but could not for his hurt.
And fearest not, that more thee hurten might,
His harmefull club he gan to hurtle hye,
All hurtlen forth, and she with Princely pace,
Therewith they gan to hurtlen greedily,
On gentle Dame, so hurtlesse, and so trew:
Came hurtling in full fierce, and forst the knight retyre.
Now hurtling round aduantage for to take:
To salue his hurts, that yet still freshly bled.
Found neuer helpe, who neuer would his hurts impart.
All healed of his hurts and woundes wide,
And where he hits, nought knowes, & whom he hurts, nought cares.
But all your hurts may soone through te[m]perance be easd.
That ryde he could not, till his hurts he did amend.
The hurts whereof me now from battell stay,
And handling soft the hurts, which she did get.
Through her late hurts, and through that haplesse wound,
That in short space his hurts he had redrest,
But that same Ladies hurts no herbe he found,
Can remedy such hurts; such hurts are hellish paine.
Can remedy such hurts; such hurts are hellish paine.
And wholesome Statutes to her husband brought;
Whom fortune for her husband would allot,
(Blacke Herebus thy husband is the foe
Or care of credite, or of husband old,
The whiles her husband ranne with sory haste,
Into an heard, farre from the husband farme,
Her husband Vulcan whylome for her sake,
To bring it to her husband new ordained,
And with her husband vnder hand so wrought,
The wofull husbandman doth lowd complaine,
And the sad husbandmans long hope doth throw
Like as a withered tree through husbands toyle
She threw her husbands murdred infant out,
After her Noble husbands late decesse;
The wrathfull Prince, & wrought her husbands peace,
But at these straungers presence euery one did hush.
A gentle Husher, Vanitie by name
Much can they prayse the trees so straight and hy,
And clash their shields, and shake their swords on hy,
Forth to an hill, that was both steepe and hy;
King Ryence caused to be hanged hy
She fastned hath her foot, which standes so hy,
For much more eath to tell the starres on hy,
And place deserued with the Gods on hy.
Which she with wrongs hath heaped vp so hy,
He pulleth downe, he setteth vp on hy;
So louedst thou the lusty Hyacinct,
Some deepe empurpled as the Hyacint,
Fresh Hyacinthus, Phoebus paramoure,
Like a faire Lady, but did fowle Duessa hyde.
Cruell reuenge, which he in hart did hyde,
Henceforth thy hated face for euer hyde,
And in an heaped furrow did thee hyde,
Within the riuer, which the same did hyde:
And wrestle wantonly, ne car'd to hyde,
But since thy faithfull zeale lets me not hyde
She gan auize, where else he mote him hyde:
Which the faire feature of her limbs did hyde,
All his demeasnure from his sight did hyde:
But hearken to his lore, and all his counsell hyde.
And now sad shadowes gan the world to hyde,
The more that she it sought to couer and to hyde.
And there her selfe did hyde from his hard tyranny.
Through the thick prease, there thinking him to hyde.
For such a dismall deed, their guilt to hyde:
Behind the bushes, where she her did hyde,
Vnder blake stole hyding her bayted hooke,
Which in false griefe hyding his harmefull guile,
Or like the hell-borne Hydra, which they faine
Spring-headed Hydraes, and sea-shouldring Whales,
A shrilling trompet sownded from on hye,
An hideous Geant horrible and hye,
His heauie hand he heaued vp on hye,
And triple crowne set on her head full hye,
Like to an Almond tree ymounted hye
His weapon huge, that heaued was on hye
In their trinall triplicities on hye;
To see the Redcrosse thus aduaunced hye;
With feeble hands then stretched forth on hye,
In chiefe degree are heaped vp on hye:
And noble worth to be aduaunced hye:
Wherewith he smote his haughty crest so hye,
Should be his pray. And therefore still on hye
His harmefull club he gan to hurtle hye,
To th'vpper part, where was aduaunced hye
Worthy of heauen and hye felicitie,
Then hurling vp his harmefull blade on hye,
As when a windy tempest bloweth hye,
That euer brandished bright steele on hye:
Tho lifting vp his vertuous staffe on hye,
The painted flowres, the trees vpshooting hye,
Through whose bright ventayle lifted vp on hye
All holding crosses in their hands on hye,
Is built of hollow billowes heaped hye,
Of many wretches set his triumphes hye,
From top of Hemus, by him heaped hye;
He said; ï¿½ soueraigne Lord that sit'st on hye,
Of which full proud, himselfe vp rearing hye,
Wayting when as the Antheme should be sung on hye.
Bearing his sixe deformed heads on hye,
To tell the sands, or count the starres on hye,
Still holding vp her suppliant hands on hye,
And mounting straight vpon a charret hye,
With many towres, and tarras mounted hye,
Mongst many foes, him selfe did faster hye;
And flyes away as fast as he can hye,
With ragged weedes, and lockes vpstaring hye,
But likest it to an Hyena was,
And finding not th'Hyena to be slaine,
They wist their houre was spe[n]t; the[n] each to rest him hyes.
And Hygate made the meare thereof by West,
